title: 115_hr1761
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" and addresses sexual exploitation of children. The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" amends Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code to address the sexual exploitation of children, including provisions related to employing minors for sexually explicit conduct, producing visual depictions of such conduct, and transmitting live visual depictions. The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" amends Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code to address the sexual exploitation of children. It includes provisions related to minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct, assisting others in such conduct, and transporting minors for the production or transmission of visual depictions of such conduct. Parents or guardians who knowingly permit minors to engage in sexually explicit conduct will also be punished. The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" amends Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code to address the sexual exploitation of children. It includes provisions related to minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct, assisting others in such conduct, and transporting minors for the production or transmission of visual depictions of such conduct. Parents or guardians who knowingly permit minors to engage in sexually explicit conduct will also be punished as provided under subsection (e). The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" amends Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code to address the sexual exploitation of children. It includes provisions related to minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct, assisting others in such conduct, and transporting minors for the production or transmission of visual depictions of such conduct. The circumstances referred to in subsections (a) and (b) involve knowing or having reason to know that visual depictions will be transported, transmitted, or mailed using interstate or foreign commerce, and that the materials used have been transported in interstate or foreign commerce. The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" amends Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code to address the sexual exploitation of children. It includes provisions related to minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct, assisting others in such conduct, and transporting minors for the production or transmission of visual depictions of such conduct. The act specifies that criminal charges can be brought if the visual depiction of a minor engaged in sexually explicit conduct is transported or transmitted using interstate or foreign commerce, or if any part of the offense occurs within U.S. territories or possessions. Additionally, no criminal charge can be brought against electronic communication service providers or remote computing service providers unless they intentionally transmit a visual depiction of a minor engaged in sexually explicit conduct with actual knowledge of the content. The "Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017" prohibits the depiction of a minor engaged in sexually explicit conduct, and criminal charges are only allowed if not barred by section 2258B. Section 2258B of title 18, United States Code is amended to provide limited liability for individuals responding to search warrants or legal process. Passed by the House of Representatives on May 25, 2017.
